solution: Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 2 and 7.\nThe LCD is 14.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 14.\n$\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{1 \\times 7}{2 \\times 7} = \\frac{7}{14}$\n$\\frac{1}{7} = \\frac{1 \\times 2}{7 \\times 2} = \\frac{2}{14}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{7}{14} - \\frac{2}{14} = \\frac{5}{14}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 7 and 5.\nThe LCD is 35.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 35.\n$\\frac{6}{7} = \\frac{6 \\times 5}{7 \\times 5} = \\frac{30}{35}$\n$\\frac{2}{5} = \\frac{2 \\times 7}{5 \\times 7} = \\frac{14}{35}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{30}{35} - \\frac{14}{35} = \\frac{16}{35}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 3 and 2.\nThe LCD is 6.
Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 6.\n$\\frac{2}{3} = \\frac{2 \\times 2}{3 \\times 2} = \\frac{4}{6}$\n$\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{1 \\times 3}{2 \\times 3} = \\frac{3}{6}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{4}{6} - \\frac{3}{6} = \\frac{1}{6}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 4 and 5.\nThe LCD is 20.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 20.\n$\\frac{3}{4} = \\frac{3 \\times 5}{4 \\times 5} = \\frac{15}{20}$\n$\\frac{3}{5} = \\frac{3 \\times 4}{5 \\times 4} = \\frac{12}{20}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{15}{20} - \\frac{12}{20} = \\frac{3}{20}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 7 and 12.\nThe LCD is 84.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 84.\n$\\frac{2}{7} = \\frac{2 \\times 12}{7 \\times 12} = \\frac{24}{84}$\n$\\frac{3}{12} = \\frac{3 \\times 7}{12 \\times 7} = \\frac{21}{84}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{24}{84} - \\frac{21}{84} = \\frac{3}{84}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{3}{84} = \\frac{1}{28}$
You can use 12 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{1}{2}$ by 6 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{1 \\times 6}{2 \\times 6} = \\frac{6}{12}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{6}{12} - \\frac{5}{12} = \\frac{1}{12}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 4 and 3.\nThe LCD is 12.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 12.\n$\\frac{2}{4} = \\frac{2 \\times 3}{4 \\times 3} = \\frac{6}{12}$\n$\\frac{1}{3} = \\frac{1 \\times 4}{3 \\times 4} = \\frac{4}{12}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{6}{12} - \\frac{4}{12} = \\frac{2}{12}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{2}{12} = \\frac{1}{6}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 2 and 7.\nThe LCD is 14.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 14.\n$\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{1 \\times 7}{2 \\times 7} = \\frac{7}{14}$\n$\\frac{3}{7} = \\frac{3 \\times 2}{7 \\times 2} = \\frac{6}{14}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{7}{14} - \\frac{6}{14} = \\frac{1}{14}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 7 and 10.\nThe LCD is 70.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 70.\n$\\frac{6}{7} = \\frac{6 \\times 10}{7 \\times 10} = \\frac{60}{70}$\n$\\frac{2}{10} = \\frac{2 \\times 7}{10 \\times 7} = \\frac{14}{70}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{60}{70} - \\frac{14}{70} = \\frac{46}{70}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{46}{70} = \\frac{23}{35}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 9 and 4.\nThe LCD is 36.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 36.\n$\\frac{8}{9} = \\frac{8 \\times 4}{9 \\times 4} = \\frac{32}{36}$\n$\\frac{2}{4} = \\frac{2 \\times 9}{4 \\times 9} = \\frac{18}{36}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{32}{36} - \\frac{18}{36} = \\frac{14}{36}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{14}{36} = \\frac{7}{18}$
You can use 12 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{2}{3}$ by 4 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{2 \\times 4}{3 \\times 4} = \\frac{8}{12}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{8}{12} - \\frac{2}{12} = \\frac{6}{12}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{6}{12} = \\frac{1}{2}$
You can use 8 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{1}{2}$ by 4 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{1 \\times 4}{2 \\times 4} = \\frac{4}{8}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{4}{8} - \\frac{2}{8} = \\frac{2}{8}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{2}{8} = \\frac{1}{4}$
You can use 9 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{2}{3}$ by 3 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{2 \\times 3}{3 \\times 3} = \\frac{6}{9}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{8}{9} - \\frac{6}{9} = \\frac{2}{9}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 6 and 9.\nThe LCD is 18.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 18.\n$\\frac{4}{6} = \\frac{4 \\times 3}{6 \\times 3} = \\frac{12}{18}$\n$\\frac{4}{9} = \\frac{4 \\times 2}{9 \\times 2} = \\frac{8}{18}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{12}{18} - \\frac{8}{18} = \\frac{4}{18}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{4}{18} = \\frac{2}{9}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 11 and 10.\nThe LCD is 110.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 110.\n$\\frac{3}{11} = \\frac{3 \\times 10}{11 \\times 10} = \\frac{30}{110}$\n$\\frac{2}{10} = \\frac{2 \\times 11}{10 \\times 11} = \\frac{22}{110}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{30}{110} - \\frac{22}{110} = \\frac{8}{110}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{8}{110} = \\frac{4}{55}$
You can use 8 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{2}{4}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{2 \\times 2}{4 \\times 2} = \\frac{4}{8}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{4}{8} - \\frac{2}{8} = \\frac{2}{8}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{2}{8} = \\frac{1}{4}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 2 and 11.\nThe LCD is 22.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 22.\n$\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{1 \\times 11}{2 \\times 11} = \\frac{11}{22}$\n$\\frac{3}{11} = \\frac{3 \\times 2}{11 \\times 2} = \\frac{6}{22}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{11}{22} - \\frac{6}{22} = \\frac{5}{22}$
You can use 6 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{2}{3}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{2 \\times 2}{3 \\times 2} = \\frac{4}{6}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{4}{6} - \\frac{4}{6} = \\frac{0}{6} = 0$
You can use 10 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{1}{2}$ by 5 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{1 \\times 5}{2 \\times 5} = \\frac{5}{10}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{6}{10} - \\frac{5}{10} = \\frac{1}{10}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 5 and 2.\nThe LCD is 10.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 10.\n$\\frac{4}{5} = \\frac{4 \\times 2}{5 \\times 2} = \\frac{8}{10}$\n$\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{1 \\times 5}{2 \\times 5} = \\frac{5}{10}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{8}{10} - \\frac{5}{10} = \\frac{3}{10}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 5 and 8.\nThe LCD is 40.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 40.\n$\\frac{2}{5} = \\frac{2 \\times 8}{5 \\times 8} = \\frac{16}{40}$\n$\\frac{2}{8} = \\frac{2 \\times 5}{8 \\times 5} = \\frac{10}{40}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{16}{40} - \\frac{10}{40} = \\frac{6}{40}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{6}{40} = \\frac{3}{20}$
You can use 8 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{3}{4}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{3 \\times 2}{4 \\times 2} = \\frac{6}{8}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{6}{8} - \\frac{1}{8} = \\frac{5}{8}$
You can use 4 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{1}{2}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{1 \\times 2}{2 \\times 2} = \\frac{2}{4}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{2}{4} - \\frac{2}{4} = \\frac{0}{4} = 0$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 9 and 6.\nThe LCD is 18.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 18.\n$\\frac{8}{9} = \\frac{8 \\times 2}{9 \\times 2} = \\frac{16}{18}$\n$\\frac{1}{6} = \\frac{1 \\times 3}{6 \\times 3} = \\frac{3}{18}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{16}{18} - \\frac{3}{18} = \\frac{13}{18}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 10 and 6.\nThe LCD is 30.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 30.\n$\\frac{8}{10} = \\frac{8 \\times 3}{10 \\times 3} = \\frac{24}{30}$\n$\\frac{4}{6} = \\frac{4 \\times 5}{6 \\times 5} = \\frac{20}{30}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{24}{30} - \\frac{20}{30} = \\frac{4}{30}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{4}{30} = \\frac{2}{15}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 2 and 11.\nThe LCD is 22.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 22.\n$\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{1 \\times 11}{2 \\times 11} = \\frac{11}{22}$\n$\\frac{2}{11} = \\frac{2 \\times 2}{11 \\times 2} = \\frac{4}{22}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{11}{22} - \\frac{4}{22} = \\frac{7}{22}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 9 and 10.\nThe LCD is 90.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 90.\n$\\frac{5}{9} = \\frac{5 \\times 10}{9 \\times 10} = \\frac{50}{90}$\n$\\frac{2}{10} = \\frac{2 \\times 9}{10 \\times 9} = \\frac{18}{90}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{50}{90} - \\frac{18}{90} = \\frac{32}{90}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{32}{90} = \\frac{16}{45}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 6 and 11.\nThe LCD is 66.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 66.\n$\\frac{4}{6} = \\frac{4 \\times 11}{6 \\times 11} = \\frac{44}{66}$\n$\\frac{1}{11} = \\frac{1 \\times 6}{11 \\times 6} = \\frac{6}{66}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{44}{66} - \\frac{6}{66} = \\frac{38}{66}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{38}{66} = \\frac{19}{33}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 11 and 7.\nThe LCD is 77.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 77.\n$\\frac{6}{11} = \\frac{6 \\times 7}{11 \\times 7} = \\frac{42}{77}$\n$\\frac{1}{7} = \\frac{1 \\times 11}{7 \\times 11} = \\frac{11}{77}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{42}{77} - \\frac{11}{77} = \\frac{31}{77}$
You can use 8 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{1}{2}$ by 4 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{1 \\times 4}{2 \\times 4} = \\frac{4}{8}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{5}{8} - \\frac{4}{8} = \\frac{1}{8}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 9 and 6.\nThe LCD is 18.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 18.\n$\\frac{7}{9} = \\frac{7 \\times 2}{9 \\times 2} = \\frac{14}{18}$\n$\\frac{2}{6} = \\frac{2 \\times 3}{6 \\times 3} = \\frac{6}{18}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{14}{18} - \\frac{6}{18} = \\frac{8}{18}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{8}{18} = \\frac{4}{9}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 7 and 10.\nThe LCD is 70.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 70.\n$\\frac{4}{7} = \\frac{4 \\times 10}{7 \\times 10} = \\frac{40}{70}$\n$\\frac{1}{10} = \\frac{1 \\times 7}{10 \\times 7} = \\frac{7}{70}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{40}{70} - \\frac{7}{70} = \\frac{33}{70}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 7 and 11.\nThe LCD is 77.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 77.\n$\\frac{6}{7} = \\frac{6 \\times 11}{7 \\times 11} = \\frac{66}{77}$\n$\\frac{9}{11} = \\frac{9 \\times 7}{11 \\times 7} = \\frac{63}{77}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{66}{77} - \\frac{63}{77} = \\frac{3}{77}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 2 and 11.\nThe LCD is 22.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 22.\n$\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{1 \\times 11}{2 \\times 11} = \\frac{11}{22}$\n$\\frac{5}{11} = \\frac{5 \\times 2}{11 \\times 2} = \\frac{10}{22}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{11}{22} - \\frac{10}{22} = \\frac{1}{22}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 3 and 5.\nThe LCD is 15.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 15.\n$\\frac{2}{3} = \\frac{2 \\times 5}{3 \\times 5} = \\frac{10}{15}$\n$\\frac{1}{5} = \\frac{1 \\times 3}{5 \\times 3} = \\frac{3}{15}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{10}{15} - \\frac{3}{15} = \\frac{7}{15}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 5 and 7.\nThe LCD is 35.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 35.\n$\\frac{4}{5} = \\frac{4 \\times 7}{5 \\times 7} = \\frac{28}{35}$\n$\\frac{2}{7} = \\frac{2 \\times 5}{7 \\times 5} = \\frac{10}{35}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{28}{35} - \\frac{10}{35} = \\frac{18}{35}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 10 and 11.\nThe LCD is 110.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 110.\n$\\frac{1}{10} = \\frac{1 \\times 11}{10 \\times 11} = \\frac{11}{110}$\n$\\frac{1}{11} = \\frac{1 \\times 10}{11 \\times 10} = \\frac{10}{110}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{11}{110} - \\frac{10}{110} = \\frac{1}{110}$
You can use 10 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{3}{5}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{3 \\times 2}{5 \\times 2} = \\frac{6}{10}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{6}{10} - \\frac{4}{10} = \\frac{2}{10}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{2}{10} = \\frac{1}{5}$
You can use 10 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{4}{5}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{4 \\times 2}{5 \\times 2} = \\frac{8}{10}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{9}{10} - \\frac{8}{10} = \\frac{1}{10}$
You can use 12 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{2}{3}$ by 4 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{2 \\times 4}{3 \\times 4} = \\frac{8}{12}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{8}{12} - \\frac{1}{12} = \\frac{7}{12}$
You can use 6 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{1}{2}$ by 3 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{1 \\times 3}{2 \\times 3} = \\frac{3}{6}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{5}{6} - \\frac{3}{6} = \\frac{2}{6}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{2}{6} = \\frac{1}{3}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 5 and 8.\nThe LCD is 40.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 40.\n$\\frac{4}{5} = \\frac{4 \\times 8}{5 \\times 8} = \\frac{32}{40}$\n$\\frac{2}{8} = \\frac{2 \\times 5}{8 \\times 5} = \\frac{10}{40}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{32}{40} - \\frac{10}{40} = \\frac{22}{40}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{22}{40} = \\frac{11}{20}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 7 and 3.\nThe LCD is 21.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 21.\n$\\frac{4}{7} = \\frac{4 \\times 3}{7 \\times 3} = \\frac{12}{21}$\n$\\frac{1}{3} = \\frac{1 \\times 7}{3 \\times 7} = \\frac{7}{21}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{12}{21} - \\frac{7}{21} = \\frac{5}{21}$
You can use 6 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{1}{3}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{1 \\times 2}{3 \\times 2} = \\frac{2}{6}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{2}{6} - \\frac{1}{6} = \\frac{1}{6}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 8 and 10.\nThe LCD is 40.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 40.\n$\\frac{7}{8} = \\frac{7 \\times 5}{8 \\times 5} = \\frac{35}{40}$\n$\\frac{2}{10} = \\frac{2 \\times 4}{10 \\times 4} = \\frac{8}{40}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{35}{40} - \\frac{8}{40} = \\frac{27}{40}$
You can use 10 as the common denominator.\nMultiply the numerator and the denominator of $\\frac{1}{5}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.\n$\\frac{1 \\times 2}{5 \\times 2} = \\frac{2}{10}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{8}{10} - \\frac{2}{10} = \\frac{6}{10}$
Simplify the fraction.\n$\\frac{6}{10} = \\frac{3}{5}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 4 and 10.\nThe LCD is 20.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 20.\n$\\frac{3}{4} = \\frac{3 \\times 5}{4 \\times 5} = \\frac{15}{20}$\n$\\frac{6}{10} = \\frac{6 \\times 2}{10 \\times 2} = \\frac{12}{20}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{15}{20} - \\frac{12}{20} = \\frac{3}{20}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 9 and 6.\nThe LCD is 18.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 18.\n$\\frac{8}{9} = \\frac{8 \\times 2}{9 \\times 2} = \\frac{16}{18}$\n$\\frac{3}{6} = \\frac{3 \\times 3}{6 \\times 3} = \\frac{9}{18}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{16}{18} - \\frac{9}{18} = \\frac{7}{18}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 5 and 8.\nThe LCD is 40.

Convert both fractions to equivalent fractions with denominator 40.\n$\\frac{2}{5} = \\frac{2 \\times 8}{5 \\times 8} = \\frac{16}{40}$\n$\\frac{1}{8} = \\frac{1 \\times 5}{8 \\times 5} = \\frac{5}{40}$
Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.\n$\\frac{16}{40} - \\frac{5}{40} = \\frac{11}{40}$
